intro: Haplopappus brickellioides, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive foliage. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh, dry climates. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and yellow, often clustered in a single head. Haplopappus brickellioides is also noted for its ability to thrive in disturbed soils and its role in supporting local pollinators.
